Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,
or co-ops for short, around the world. Co-ops are a big part 
of the global economy: they employ 280 million people—
10% of the world’s workforce and the equivalent of over $2 trillion
flow through their doors every year. How is it possible that a business 
with 10,000 workers doesn’t have a CEO? To answer that, we have to talk about what
a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,
they could negotiate prices, which allowed all of them to buy stuff
they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers
wasn't the world's first co-op, but it was the first to publicize 
its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance
companies are financial sector co-ops. And when farmers or other producers come
together, that's a producer co-op. And then there are worker co-ops, like Mondragon in Spain or 
The Cheeseboard in Berkeley, California, which are founded to provide jobs
to people in the community. Some consumer co-ops, like Park Slope, require their members to work shifts 
in the store. In exchange for their work, members pay 
15 to 50% less for groceries, and they influence what products
are— or aren’t— sold there. Three crucial things to know about co-ops: first, all co-ops are jointly
owned by their members, whether those members are consumers,
producers, workers, or whoever. Unlike traditional companies, 
which can have outside shareholders, all owners of a co-op are also members. Second, co-ops are not founded
to maximize profit. Many do turn a significant profit, 
but that’s not their core mission. So evaluating a co-op purely 
by traditional business metrics ignores the most important reason
for their existence: how well do they serve their members? And third: co-ops are controlled
democratically by their members. But how do decisions get made? It varies. At a small worker co-op
like The Cheeseboard, day-to-day operational decisions
are just made by the workers. As co-ops get larger, they do institute
some form of leadership or management. Park Slope has a general manager 
who leads the 80 or so employees. And the largest network of worker 
and consumer co-ops in the world, Mondragon, has a president 
and managers who lead the roughly 30,000 worker-owners 
and 50,000 contract workers. But leadership roles in a co-op are very
different than in a traditional company. The leadership implements policies
that its members or worker-owners have agreed upon, by vote. And at Mondragon workers, 
can vote to fire the president. At a co-op, there’s no single person with overarching, top-down power 
over everyone else, like a CEO would have 
in a traditional company. Meanwhile, in both co-ops 
and traditional companies, major company-wide decisions
are made by voting. But who votes and how is wildly different. In a traditional company, voting rights 
usually come with shares of stock. The more shares you own, 
the more votes you have. Take Alphabet, 
the parent company of Google: there are thousands of shareholders, but the two founders control 51% 
of the votes and therefore the direction 
of the company. In a co-op, every member 
has the right to vote, and in most co-ops,
every member gets one vote. That difference results 
in radically different policies than you’d find at traditional companies. For example, Mondragon limits the salaries
of its management to about 6 times what the lowest paid 
worker makes. In Spain, CEOs of traditional companies 
make, on average, 143 times as much as a typical worker. At Park Slope, there’s a monthly 
general meeting, where any member can show up to vote, and a motion needs a
simple majority to pass. It then gets taken up by
the Board of directors, which is composed of co-op members,
for official approval. At The Cheeseboard, the worker-owners 
try to reach consensus on major decisions. This means that some decisions
can take a long time. For example, in the late 1970s, the workers debated whether to post
a sign outside declaring that The Cheeseboard was a collective
for one and a half years. But the extensive discussion, 
and disagreements, around that decision made it a solid one— The Cheeseboard still advertises
the fact that it’s a collective almost 50 years later. And that’s not all that’s
working well at co-ops. Studies in the UK show that co-op
start-ups are almost half as likely to close within five years
as traditional businesses. And in one study, 
researchers polled 600 workers at two in-home healthcare businesses: one was a worker co-op and the other
was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Approximately how many cooperatives, or co-ops, are there around the world?
Options: A. 1 million, B. 2 million, C. 3 million, D. 4 million
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why a business with 10,000 workers, like the Park Slope Food Co-op, doesn't have a CEO? Options: A. They're a small business that is owned and controlled by its members, not a traditional company with a CEO., B. They're a co-op, and co-ops are not founded to maximize profit., C. They're a non-profit organization., D. They can't afford to pay one. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is a key principle that guides co-ops to this day? Options: A. Co-ops are jointly owned by their members., B. Co-ops are controlled by a single CEO., C. Co-ops are only for consumer co-ops., D. Co-ops are founded to maximize profit. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the main difference between a traditional company and a co-op in terms of voting rights? Options: A. In a traditional company, every member has the right to vote, and in a co-op, only shareholders have the right to vote., B. In a traditional company, voting rights usually come with shares of stock, but in a co-op, every member gets one vote., C. In a traditional company, voting rights are determined by the CEO, but in a co-op, voting rights are determined by the members., D. In a traditional company, voting rights are determined by the Board of Directors, but in a co-op, voting rights are determined by the members. Correct Option: B
Question 4: What is the name of the largest network of worker and consumer co-ops in the world? Options: A. Mondragon, B. Park Slope Food Co-op, C. The Cheeseboard, D. REI Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the main reason why co-op start-ups are almost half as likely to close within five years as traditional businesses? Options: A. Co-ops have more resources available to them., B. Co-ops have a more stable business model., C. Co-ops are more adaptable to changing market conditions., D. Co-ops have a more democratic decision-making process, which leads to more engaged and committed members. Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the name of the study that found that co-op workers were about 40% happier with their jobs than traditional company workers? Options: A. The Cheeseboard study, B. The Mondragon study, C. The Park Slope Food Co-op study, D. The in-home healthcare study Correct Option: D
Question 7: What is the main difference between a traditional company and a co-op in terms of leadership roles? Options: A. In a traditional company, leadership roles are determined by the CEO, but in a co-op, leadership roles are determined by the members., B. In a traditional company, leadership roles are determined by the Board of Directors, but in a co-op, leadership roles are determined by the CEO., C. In a traditional company, leadership roles are determined by the shareholders, but in a co-op, leadership roles are determined by the members., D. In a traditional company, leadership roles are determined by the employees, but in a co-op, leadership roles are determined by the members. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the principle that guides co-ops to this day, and was first publicized by the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers? Options: A. The principle of joint ownership, B. The principle of democratic decision-making, C. The principle of solidarity, D. The principle of cooperation Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the main reason why co-ops are not founded to maximize profit? Options: A. Co-ops are founded to serve their members., B. Co-ops are founded to provide jobs to people in the community., C. Co-ops are founded to make a profit, but not to maximize it., D. Co-ops are founded to provide a service to the community. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main difference between a traditional company and a co-op in terms of salaries? Options: A. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the CEO, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the members., B. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the Board of Directors, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the CEO., C. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the shareholders, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the members., D. In a traditional company, salaries are limited to 6 times the lowest paid worker, but in a co-op, salaries are not limited. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
None of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. However, I can suggest a generated MCQ that is somewhat related to the topic of cooperatives.

The ground truth MCQ asks about the approximate number of cooperatives around the world. While none of the generated MCQs ask this exact question, Question 4 asks about the name of the largest network of worker and consumer co-ops in the world, which is related to the topic of cooperatives.

However, if I had to choose a generated MCQ that is closest to the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, I would suggest Question 8, which asks about the principle that guides co-ops to this day, and was first publicized by the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers. This question is not directly related to the number of cooperatives, but it does provide some background information on the history and principles of cooperatives.

But, if I really had to choose one, I would say that none of the generated MCQs match the ground truth MCQ, but if I had to pick one, I would say Question 2, which asks about a key principle that guides co-ops to this day, and it mentions that co-ops are jointly owned by their members, and it provides some information about the number of members, and workers in co-ops.

However, I think the best answer is that there is no generated MCQ that matches the ground truth MCQ.

After reevaluating the generated MCQs I can tell you that the one that is the most similar is: 

 Question 2

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,
or co-ops for short, around the world. Co-ops are a big part 
of the global economy: they employ 280 million people—
10% of the world’s workforce and the equivalent of over $2 trillion
flow through their doors every year. How is it possible that a business 
with 10,000 workers doesn’t have a CEO? To answer that, we have to talk about what
a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,
they could negotiate prices, which allowed all of them to buy stuff
they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers
wasn't the world's first co-op, but it was the first to publicize 
its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance
companies are financial sector co-ops. And when farmers or other producers come
together, that's a producer co-op. And then there are worker co-ops, like Mondragon in Spain or 
The Cheeseboard in Berkeley, California, which are founded to provide jobs
to people in the community. Some consumer co-ops, like Park Slope, require their members to work shifts 
in the store. In exchange for their work, members pay 
15 to 50% less for groceries, and they influence what products
are— or aren’t— sold there. Three crucial things to know about co-ops: first, all co-ops are jointly
owned by their members, whether those members are consumers,
producers, workers, or whoever. Unlike traditional companies, 
which can have outside shareholders, all owners of a co-op are also members. Second, co-ops are not founded
to maximize profit. Many do turn a significant profit, 
but that’s not their core mission. So evaluating a co-op purely 
by traditional business metrics ignores the most important reason
for their existence: how well do they serve their members? And third: co-ops are controlled
democratically by their members. But how do decisions get made? It varies. At a small worker co-op
like The Cheeseboard, day-to-day operational decisions
are just made by the workers. As co-ops get larger, they do institute
some form of leadership or management. Park Slope has a general manager 
who leads the 80 or so employees. And the largest network of worker 
and consumer co-ops in the world, Mondragon, has a president 
and managers who lead the roughly 30,000 worker-owners 
and 50,000 contract workers. But leadership roles in a co-op are very
different than in a traditional company. The leadership implements policies
that its members or worker-owners have agreed upon, by vote. And at Mondragon workers, 
can vote to fire the president. At a co-op, there’s no single person with overarching, top-down power 
over everyone else, like a CEO would have 
in a traditional company. Meanwhile, in both co-ops 
and traditional companies, major company-wide decisions
are made by voting. But who votes and how is wildly different. In a traditional company, voting rights 
usually come with shares of stock. The more shares you own, 
the more votes you have. Take Alphabet, 
the parent company of Google: there are thousands of shareholders, but the two founders control 51% 
of the votes and therefore the direction 
of the company. In a co-op, every member 
has the right to vote, and in most co-ops,
every member gets one vote. That difference results 
in radically different policies than you’d find at traditional companies. For example, Mondragon limits the salaries
of its management to about 6 times what the lowest paid 
worker makes. In Spain, CEOs of traditional companies 
make, on average, 143 times as much as a typical worker. At Park Slope, there’s a monthly 
general meeting, where any member can show up to vote, and a motion needs a
simple majority to pass. It then gets taken up by
the Board of directors, which is composed of co-op members,
for official approval. At The Cheeseboard, the worker-owners 
try to reach consensus on major decisions. This means that some decisions
can take a long time. For example, in the late 1970s, the workers debated whether to post
a sign outside declaring that The Cheeseboard was a collective
for one and a half years. But the extensive discussion, 
and disagreements, around that decision made it a solid one— The Cheeseboard still advertises
the fact that it’s a collective almost 50 years later. And that’s not all that’s
working well at co-ops. Studies in the UK show that co-op
start-ups are almost half as likely to close within five years
as traditional businesses. And in one study, 
researchers polled 600 workers at two in-home healthcare businesses: one was a worker co-op and the other
was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers was the first
Options: A. Co-op, B. Co-op to publish their principles, C. Co-op of weavers, D. Publicly traded company
Correct Option: B

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8. 

This question is about the principle that guides co-ops to this day, and was first publicized by the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers. Although it does not directly ask if the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers was the first co-op to publish its principles, it does relate to the same topic and idea.

However, it's worth noting that none of the generated MCQs perfectly match the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ specifically asks about the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers being the first co-op to publish its principles, which is not directly asked in any of the generated MCQs.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,
or co-ops for short, around the world. Co-ops are a big part 
of the global economy: they employ 280 million people—
10% of the world’s workforce and the equivalent of over $2 trillion
flow through their doors every year. How is it possible that a business 
with 10,000 workers doesn’t have a CEO? To answer that, we have to talk about what
a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,
they could negotiate prices, which allowed all of them to buy stuff
they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers
wasn't the world's first co-op, but it was the first to publicize 
its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance
companies are financial sector co-ops. And when farmers or other producers come
together, that's a producer co-op. And then there are worker co-ops, like Mondragon in Spain or 
The Cheeseboard in Berkeley, California, which are founded to provide jobs
to people in the community. Some consumer co-ops, like Park Slope, require their members to work shifts 
in the store. In exchange for their work, members pay 
15 to 50% less for groceries, and they influence what products
are— or aren’t— sold there. Three crucial things to know about co-ops: first, all co-ops are jointly
owned by their members, whether those members are consumers,
producers, workers, or whoever. Unlike traditional companies, 
which can have outside shareholders, all owners of a co-op are also members. Second, co-ops are not founded
to maximize profit. Many do turn a significant profit, 
but that’s not their core mission. So evaluating a co-op purely 
by traditional business metrics ignores the most important reason
for their existence: how well do they serve their members? And third: co-ops are controlled
democratically by their members. But how do decisions get made? It varies. At a small worker co-op
like The Cheeseboard, day-to-day operational decisions
are just made by the workers. As co-ops get larger, they do institute
some form of leadership or management. Park Slope has a general manager 
who leads the 80 or so employees. And the largest network of worker 
and consumer co-ops in the world, Mondragon, has a president 
and managers who lead the roughly 30,000 worker-owners 
and 50,000 contract workers. But leadership roles in a co-op are very
different than in a traditional company. The leadership implements policies
that its members or worker-owners have agreed upon, by vote. And at Mondragon workers, 
can vote to fire the president. At a co-op, there’s no single person with overarching, top-down power 
over everyone else, like a CEO would have 
in a traditional company. Meanwhile, in both co-ops 
and traditional companies, major company-wide decisions
are made by voting. But who votes and how is wildly different. In a traditional company, voting rights 
usually come with shares of stock. The more shares you own, 
the more votes you have. Take Alphabet, 
the parent company of Google: there are thousands of shareholders, but the two founders control 51% 
of the votes and therefore the direction 
of the company. In a co-op, every member 
has the right to vote, and in most co-ops,
every member gets one vote. That difference results 
in radically different policies than you’d find at traditional companies. For example, Mondragon limits the salaries
of its management to about 6 times what the lowest paid 
worker makes. In Spain, CEOs of traditional companies 
make, on average, 143 times as much as a typical worker. At Park Slope, there’s a monthly 
general meeting, where any member can show up to vote, and a motion needs a
simple majority to pass. It then gets taken up by
the Board of directors, which is composed of co-op members,
for official approval. At The Cheeseboard, the worker-owners 
try to reach consensus on major decisions. This means that some decisions
can take a long time. For example, in the late 1970s, the workers debated whether to post
a sign outside declaring that The Cheeseboard was a collective
for one and a half years. But the extensive discussion, 
and disagreements, around that decision made it a solid one— The Cheeseboard still advertises
the fact that it’s a collective almost 50 years later. And that’s not all that’s
working well at co-ops. Studies in the UK show that co-op
start-ups are almost half as likely to close within five years
as traditional businesses. And in one study, 
researchers polled 600 workers at two in-home healthcare businesses: one was a worker co-op and the other
was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What makes a co-op, a co-op?
Options: A. They are jointly owned by their members, B. They are NOT founded to maximize profits, C. They are controlled democratically, by their members, D. All of the above
Correct Option: D

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main reason why a business with 10,000 workers, like the Park Slope Food Co-op, doesn't have a CEO? Options: A. Co-ops are founded to provide jobs to people in the community., C. Co-ops are founded to make a profit, but not to maximize it., D. Co-ops are founded to provide a service to the community. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main difference between a traditional company and a co-op in terms of salaries? Options: A. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the CEO, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the members., B. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the Board of Directors, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the CEO., C. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the shareholders, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the members., D. In a traditional company, salaries are limited to 6 times the lowest paid worker, but in a co-op, salaries are not limited. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,
or co-ops for short, around the world. Co-ops are a big part 
of the global economy: they employ 280 million people—
10% of the world’s workforce and the equivalent of over $2 trillion
flow through their doors every year. How is it possible that a business 
with 10,000 workers doesn’t have a CEO? To answer that, we have to talk about what
a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,
they could negotiate prices, which allowed all of them to buy stuff
they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers
wasn't the world's first co-op, but it was the first to publicize 
its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance
companies are financial sector co-ops. And when farmers or other producers come
together, that's a producer co-op. And then there are worker co-ops, like Mondragon in Spain or 
The Cheeseboard in Berkeley, California, which are founded to provide jobs
to people in the community. Some consumer co-ops, like Park Slope, require their members to work shifts 
in the store. In exchange for their work, members pay 
15 to 50% less for groceries, and they influence what products
are— or aren’t— sold there. Three crucial things to know about co-ops: first, all co-ops are jointly
owned by their members, whether those members are consumers,
producers, workers, or whoever. Unlike traditional companies, 
which can have outside shareholders, all owners of a co-op are also members. Second, co-ops are not founded
to maximize profit. Many do turn a significant profit, 
but that’s not their core mission. So evaluating a co-op purely 
by traditional business metrics ignores the most important reason
for their existence: how well do they serve their members? And third: co-ops are controlled
democratically by their members. But how do decisions get made? It varies. At a small worker co-op
like The Cheeseboard, day-to-day operational decisions
are just made by the workers. As co-ops get larger, they do institute
some form of leadership or management. Park Slope has a general manager 
who leads the 80 or so employees. And the largest network of worker 
and consumer co-ops in the world, Mondragon, has a president 
and managers who lead the roughly 30,000 worker-owners 
and 50,000 contract workers. But leadership roles in a co-op are very
different than in a traditional company. The leadership implements policies
that its members or worker-owners have agreed upon, by vote. And at Mondragon workers, 
can vote to fire the president. At a co-op, there’s no single person with overarching, top-down power 
over everyone else, like a CEO would have 
in a traditional company. Meanwhile, in both co-ops 
and traditional companies, major company-wide decisions
are made by voting. But who votes and how is wildly different. In a traditional company, voting rights 
usually come with shares of stock. The more shares you own, 
the more votes you have. Take Alphabet, 
the parent company of Google: there are thousands of shareholders, but the two founders control 51% 
of the votes and therefore the direction 
of the company. In a co-op, every member 
has the right to vote, and in most co-ops,
every member gets one vote. That difference results 
in radically different policies than you’d find at traditional companies. For example, Mondragon limits the salaries
of its management to about 6 times what the lowest paid 
worker makes. In Spain, CEOs of traditional companies 
make, on average, 143 times as much as a typical worker. At Park Slope, there’s a monthly 
general meeting, where any member can show up to vote, and a motion needs a
simple majority to pass. It then gets taken up by
the Board of directors, which is composed of co-op members,
for official approval. At The Cheeseboard, the worker-owners 
try to reach consensus on major decisions. This means that some decisions
can take a long time. For example, in the late 1970s, the workers debated whether to post
a sign outside declaring that The Cheeseboard was a collective
for one and a half years. But the extensive discussion, 
and disagreements, around that decision made it a solid one— The Cheeseboard still advertises
the fact that it’s a collective almost 50 years later. And that’s not all that’s
working well at co-ops. Studies in the UK show that co-op
start-ups are almost half as likely to close within five years
as traditional businesses. And in one study, 
researchers polled 600 workers at two in-home healthcare businesses: one was a worker co-op and the other
was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Who guides the direction of a traditional company? How do decisions get made?
Options: A. One person. One vote., B. The person or people with the most money decide, C. The person or people with the most amount of shares decide, D. Decision-makers are appointed by the board
Correct Option: C

Question 1: What is the main reason why a business with 10,000 workers, like the Park Slope Food Co-op, doesn't have a CEO? Options: A. They're a small business that is owned and controlled by its members, not a traditional company with a CEO., B. They're a co-op, and co-ops are not founded to maximize profit., C. They're a non-profit organization., D. They can't afford to pay one. Correct Option: A
Question 2: What is a key principle that guides co-ops to this day? Options: A. Co-ops are jointly owned by their members., B. Co-ops are controlled by a single CEO., C. Co-ops are only for consumer co-ops., D. Co-ops are founded to maximize profit. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the main difference between a traditional company and a co-op in terms of voting rights? Options: A. In a traditional company, every member has the right to vote, and in a co-op, only shareholders have the right to vote., B. In a traditional company, voting rights usually come with shares of stock, but in a co-op, every member gets one vote., C. In a traditional company, voting rights are determined by the CEO, but in a co-op, voting rights are determined by the members., D. In a traditional company, voting rights are determined by the Board of Directors, but in a co-op, voting rights are determined by the members. Correct Option: B

Co-ops have a more stable business model., C. Co-ops are more adaptable to changing market conditions., D. Co-ops have a more democratic decision-making process, which leads to more engaged and committed members. Correct Option: D
Question 6: What is the name of the study that found that co-op workers were about 40% happier with their jobs than traditional company workers? Options: A. The Cheeseboard study, B. The Mondragon study, C. The Park Slope Food Co-op study, D. The in-home healthcare study Correct Option: D

In a traditional company, leadership roles are determined by the CEO, but in a co-op, leadership roles are determined by the members., B. In a traditional company, leadership roles are determined by the Board of Directors, but in a co-op, leadership roles are determined by the CEO., C. In a traditional company, leadership roles are determined by the shareholders, but in a co-op, leadership roles are determined by the members., D. In a traditional company, leadership roles are determined by the employees, but in a co-op, leadership roles are determined by the members. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is the principle that guides co-ops to this day, and was first publicized by the Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers? Options: A. The principle of joint ownership, B. The principle of democratic decision-making, C. The principle of solidarity, D. The principle of cooperation Correct Option: A
Question 9: What is the main reason why co-ops are not founded to maximize profit? Options: A. Co-ops are founded to serve their members., B. Co-ops are founded to provide jobs to people in the community., C. Co-ops are founded to make a profit, but not to maximize it., D. Co-ops are founded to provide a service to the community. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main difference between a traditional company and a co-op in terms of salaries? Options: A. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the CEO, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the members., B. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the Board of Directors, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the CEO., C. In a traditional company, salaries are determined by the shareholders, but in a co-op, salaries are determined by the members., D. In a traditional company, salaries are limited to 6 times the lowest paid worker, but in a co-op, salaries are not limited. Correct Option: A


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions ask about the main difference between a traditional company and a co-op in terms of decision-making or voting rights. The correct options for both questions also highlight the key difference between traditional companies and co-ops, which is that voting rights in traditional companies are typically tied to shares of stock, whereas in co-ops, every member has an equal vote.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 19, Question 5

**Transcript**:
There's a grocery store
in Brooklyn, New York, with sales per square foot 4 times 
as high as any other grocery store in the area. 10,000 people work there,
and it doesn’t have a CEO. This place is the Park Slope Food Co-op, and it’s one of 3 million cooperatives,
or co-ops for short, around the world. Co-ops are a big part 
of the global economy: they employ 280 million people—
10% of the world’s workforce and the equivalent of over $2 trillion
flow through their doors every year. How is it possible that a business 
with 10,000 workers doesn’t have a CEO? To answer that, we have to talk about what
a co-op is and why they were founded. Let’s rewind to 1844. A group of 28 weavers in Rochdale, England came together to create 
and co-own a store. By buying in bulk directly from suppliers,
they could negotiate prices, which allowed all of them to buy stuff
they couldn't otherwise afford. They ran the store collectively
and democratically, which was remarkable at the time. The Rochdale Society of Equitable Pioneers
wasn't the world's first co-op, but it was the first to publicize 
its principles— principles that guide co-ops to this day. Today, there are all kinds of co-ops: REI in the US and S-Group in Finland
are large consumer co-ops. Credit unions and mutual insurance

together, that's a producer co-op. And then there are worker co-ops, like Mondragon in Spain or 
The Cheeseboard in Berkeley, California, which are founded to provide jobs
to people in the community. Some consumer co-ops, like Park Slope, require their members to work shifts

15 to 50% less for groceries, and they influence what products
are— or aren’t— sold there. Three crucial things to know about co-ops: first, all co-ops are jointly

producers, workers, or whoever. Unlike traditional companies, 
which can have outside shareholders, all owners of a co-op are also members. Second, co-ops are not founded
to maximize profit. Many do turn a significant profit,

and managers who lead the roughly 30,000 worker-owners

in a traditional company. Meanwhile, in both co-ops

the more votes you have. Take Alphabet,

has the right to vote, and in most co-ops,

was a traditional company. The workers did similar work 
with similar salaries. The biggest difference? Co-op workers were 
about 40% happier with their jobs.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In a study done on businesses in the U.K, co-ops were ____ less likely to have closed down after 5 years.
Options: A. 20%, B. 30%, C. 40%, D. 50%
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Pixar...the studio behind this,
and this, and this has mastered a sort of
photo-surrealistic style where there’s a sense of cartoony-ness but most things look and feel like they
could exist in the real world. Like these fibers on Mr. Incredible’s shirt. And this tree stump and grass from
this scene from Up. Or the glimmering, out-of-focus bokeh
behind Bo Peep. And it’s not just Pixar. These movies look so similar you can barely tell they’re from
different animation studios. But when you look at these movies it’s clear that something different
is happening. These lights don’t just illuminate;
they reveal a texture. This tree in the background 
isn’t out of focus it’s just got a simplified look. And this hair looks more like
brush strokes than human hair. These films are part of a new trend that’s steering animation away from 
replicating the real world and into somewhere new. Crafting beautiful animation in CG films requires a lot of dedicated artists
to perform specialized tasks: like rendering. Rendering is the process by which
a computer takes geometry, textures, lighting, camera inputs 
and does a bunch of math to apply all that information into
a final image. Like this one. Most render engines, like the one I’m using
here, are physically based which essentially means that it tries to replicate the real world physics
of light, shadow, reflection, and more. You can see this type of rendering
all over Pixar’s work even going back to their first movie. Rex looks like he could exist 
in the real world. Every meeting we would have, everybody
brought up like the Pixar look. The Pixar look was something that was very
high quality very successful at the box office so everybody kind of wanted the Pixar look. My name is Christos Obrenetov. Christos is the CEO of Lollipop Shaders a company that builds custom shaders
and plugins for 3D software. He’s worked on tons of films including "Life of Pi", "A Christmas Carol,"
and the upcoming "Across the Spider-Verse". But before all that he worked on a bunch of films that tried to
replicate that Pixar look. Because it was reliable, popular, and safe. Part of doing a feature film is, you know,
a lot of money and a lot of time. So they were kind of chasing that Pixar dream
of having that kind of a success. So to go and spend, you know, $100 million
or more... the investors and what not
are probably saying: "It's got to look like Pixar or Disney."
Right? And that was the case for a long time. Even when studios wanted to try
something different: Disney would come up and interview for a movie
that ended up being called "Bolt". They were showing us this really cool concept
art and they're like, "Oh, it's going to be super stylized." "It's going to look like sort of like 
the concept art." And it was very exciting. I was like, "Oh, this is great." And then when the movie 
did come out I mean, Bolt is fantastic, but they made it
very, you know, that same look. Movies like "Monster House" and "A Christmas
Carol" were intended to look stylized too but ultimately they settled back into
that tried-and-true physically based rendering look. There were glimmers of more stylized approaches
in short film tests and small sequences like in Disney’s Moana. But this stylized sequence
is only about 30 seconds out of the hour and 43 minute-long film. A lot of studios have been playing with
this for a long time. But to take that risk to do a full feature film that's
very stylized in 3D I think people were scared. And that fear kept studios from making
bold choices. Until 2017 when the trailer for
"Into the Spider-Verse" dropped. It had simplified graphic bursts that felt
like comic book panels. There was no motion blur or depth of field and everything, from the characters to the
environments, was full of texture. According to one of the animation supervisors
for the project after a year and a half of work the studio was still nervous that people were
going to hate the visuals. Because they felt like they were taking too
many risks. Instead of leaning into the safe, physically
based, rendering look "Into the Spider-Verse" chose to use 
non-photorealistic rendering. To pull this off, they essentially had to
break their physically-based renderer. Instead of inputting data from lights, 
camera, and materials and receiving a realistic looking render they combined all that data with custom
data passes that tweaked things like the focus plane or the way the light worked
in an image. This combo allowed the renderer 
to produce stylized results. For example, in "Into the Spider-verse",
out of focus elements aren’t blurry. Instead, the colors split as if the screen printing on an actual 
comic book was done poorly. Lighting and shadow were approached
in new ways too. Light often reveals halftone dots. And shadows create sketchy hatch marks. But there’s more than just shading magic
happening here. Non-photorealistic renderings often use linework 2D elements like speed lines and doubles and variable frame rates to pull these frames
further away from reality and often, closer to the concept art. Just two months after its release "Into the Spider-Verse" became the highest grossing
film Sony Pictures animation had ever made. It doesn’t hold a candle to Pixar
in terms of lifetime gross: "Incredibles 2" sits at the number one spot while Spider-verse doesn’t even crack
the top 50. But, much like Pixar did in the first wave
of CG animated features "Into the Spider-Verse" redefined
the visual goals for animation studios. 2021’s "The Mitchells vs the Machines" and
2022’s "Puss in Boots" take non-photorealistic rendering in a different,
more painterly direction where out-of-focus objects 
become simplified shapes emulating the way that artists may use 
simplified marks in backgrounds "In the Mitchells vs the Machines", shadows
create different marker textures. Puss in Boots’ simplified 2D cutaways mimic
the graphic bursts of Into the Spider-verse. People were like, "Oh, this is looks really
good and it's different". So now, all future projects at studios from
DreamWorks and Imageworks and Pixar— they're looking at the next whatever, five
years or whatnot. It's all like very stylized. And that’s really exciting because non-photorealism allows animated movies
to take advantage of the things that make them special. They can be anything the imagination allows.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What style has Pixar mastered?
Options: A. Photo-impressionist, B. Photo-surrealistic, C. Photo-realistic, D. Photo-synthetic
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What style of animation is Pixar known for, where things look and feel like they could exist in the real world? Options: A. Photo-realistic, B. Photo-surrealistic, C. Stylized, D. Non-photorealistic Correct Option: B
Question 2: What is the process by which a computer takes geometry, textures, lighting, camera inputs, and applies all that information into a final image called? Options: A. Rendering, B. Animation, C. Modeling, D. Lighting[Correct answer]: A Correct Option: None
Question 3: What type of rendering is most common in the film industry, where it tries to replicate the real world physics of light, shadow, reflection, and more? Options: A. Physically based, B. Non-photorealistic, C. Stylized, D. Realistic[Correct answer]: A Correct Option: None
Question 4: Why did studios initially prefer to replicate the Pixar look in their films? Options: A. Because it was unreliable and unpopular, B. Because it was reliable, popular, and safe, C. Because it was too expensive, D. Because it was too time-consuming[Correct answer]: B Correct Option: None
Question 5: What was the name of the film that marked a turning point in the industry's approach to animation, with a stylized visuals and a non-photorealistic style? Options: A. Into the Spider-Verse, B. The Incredibles 2, C. Bolt, D. Moana[Correct answer]: A Correct Option: None
Question 6: How did the animation team for Into the Spider-Verse achieve the stylized visuals, by combining custom data passes with physically-based data? Options: A. By using a new rendering engine, B. By tweaking the focus plane and light in the image, C. By using linework and 2D elements, D. By simplifying the geometry[Correct answer]: B Correct Option: None
Question 7: What was the result of using non-photorealistic rendering in Into the Spider-Verse, with out-of-focus elements not being blurry but instead having colors split as if the screen printing on an actual comic book was done poorly? Options: A. A realistic look, B. A stylized look, C. A cartoonish look, D. A photo-realistic look[Correct answer]: B Correct Option: None
Question 8: What type of animation style is being explored in recent films like "The Mitchells vs the Machines" and "Puss in Boots", where out-of-focus objects become simplified shapes? Options: A. Non-photorealistic, B. Stylized, C. Painterly, D. Realistic[Correct answer]: C Correct Option: None
Question 9: What was the impact of the success of Into the Spider-Verse on the animation industry, with other studios looking to create more stylized and non-photorealistic films? Options: A. It led to a decline in the popularity of animation, B. It led to a shift towards more realistic films, C. It led to a shift towards more stylized and non-photorealistic films, D. It had no impact on the industry[Correct answer]: C Correct Option: None
Question 10: What is the advantage of non-photorealistic animation, allowing animated movies to take advantage of the things that make them special and be anything the imagination allows? Options: A. It allows for more realistic visuals, B. It allows for more stylized visuals, C. It allows for more creative freedom, D. It allows for more time-consuming productions[Correct answer]: C Correct Option: None


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is:

**Question 1: What style of animation is Pixar known for, where things look and feel like they could exist in the real world? Options: A. Photo-realistic, B. Photo-surrealistic, C. Stylized, D. Non-photorealistic Correct Option: B**

This question has the same intent and content as the ground truth MCQ, with similar options and a matching correct answer.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 20, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Pixar...the studio behind this,
and this, and this has mastered a sort of
photo-surrealistic style where there’s a sense of cartoony-ness but most things look and feel like they
could exist in the real world. Like these fibers on Mr. Incredible’s shirt. And this tree stump and grass from
this scene from Up. Or the glimmering, out-of-focus bokeh
behind Bo Peep. And it’s not just Pixar. These movies look so similar you can barely tell they’re from
different animation studios. But when you look at these movies it’s clear that something different
is happening. These lights don’t just illuminate;
they reveal a texture. This tree in the background 
isn’t out of focus it’s just got a simplified look. And this hair looks more like
brush strokes than human hair. These films are part of a new trend that’s steering animation away from 
replicating the real world and into somewhere new. Crafting beautiful animation in CG films requires a lot of dedicated artists
to perform specialized tasks: like rendering. Rendering is the process by which
a computer takes geometry, textures, lighting, camera inputs 
and does a bunch of math to apply all that information into
a final image. Like this one. Most render engines, like the one I’m using
here, are physically based which essentially means that it tries to replicate the real world physics
of light, shadow, reflection, and more. You can see this type of rendering
all over Pixar’s work even going back to their first movie. Rex looks like he could exist 
in the real world. Every meeting we would have, everybody
brought up like the Pixar look. The Pixar look was something that was very
high quality very successful at the box office so everybody kind of wanted the Pixar look. My name is Christos Obrenetov. Christos is the CEO of Lollipop Shaders a company that builds custom shaders
and plugins for 3D software. He’s worked on tons of films including "Life of Pi", "A Christmas Carol,"
and the upcoming "Across the Spider-Verse". But before all that he worked on a bunch of films that tried to
replicate that Pixar look. Because it was reliable, popular, and safe. Part of doing a feature film is, you know,
a lot of money and a lot of time. So they were kind of chasing that Pixar dream
of having that kind of a success. So to go and spend, you know, $100 million
or more... the investors and what not
are probably saying: "It's got to look like Pixar or Disney."
Right? And that was the case for a long time. Even when studios wanted to try
something different: Disney would come up and interview for a movie
that ended up being called "Bolt". They were showing us this really cool concept
art and they're like, "Oh, it's going to be super stylized." "It's going to look like sort of like 
the concept art." And it was very exciting. I was like, "Oh, this is great." And then when the movie 
did come out I mean, Bolt is fantastic, but they made it
very, you know, that same look. Movies like "Monster House" and "A Christmas
Carol" were intended to look stylized too but ultimately they settled back into
that tried-and-true physically based rendering look. There were glimmers of more stylized approaches
in short film tests and small sequences like in Disney’s Moana. But this stylized sequence
is only about 30 seconds out of the hour and 43 minute-long film. A lot of studios have been playing with
this for a long time. But to take that risk to do a full feature film that's
very stylized in 3D I think people were scared. And that fear kept studios from making
bold choices. Until 2017 when the trailer for
"Into the Spider-Verse" dropped. It had simplified graphic bursts that felt
like comic book panels. There was no motion blur or depth of field and everything, from the characters to the
environments, was full of texture. According to one of the animation supervisors
for the project after a year and a half of work the studio was still nervous that people were
going to hate the visuals. Because they felt like they were taking too
many risks. Instead of leaning into the safe, physically
based, rendering look "Into the Spider-Verse" chose to use 
non-photorealistic rendering. To pull this off, they essentially had to
break their physically-based renderer. Instead of inputting data from lights, 
camera, and materials and receiving a realistic looking render they combined all that data with custom
data passes that tweaked things like the focus plane or the way the light worked
in an image. This combo allowed the renderer 
to produce stylized results. For example, in "Into the Spider-verse",
out of focus elements aren’t blurry. Instead, the colors split as if the screen printing on an actual 
comic book was done poorly. Lighting and shadow were approached
in new ways too. Light often reveals halftone dots. And shadows create sketchy hatch marks. But there’s more than just shading magic
happening here. Non-photorealistic renderings often use linework 2D elements like speed lines and doubles and variable frame rates to pull these frames
further away from reality and often, closer to the concept art. Just two months after its release "Into the Spider-Verse" became the highest grossing
film Sony Pictures animation had ever made. It doesn’t hold a candle to Pixar
in terms of lifetime gross: "Incredibles 2" sits at the number one spot while Spider-verse doesn’t even crack
the top 50. But, much like Pixar did in the first wave
of CG animated features "Into the Spider-Verse" redefined
the visual goals for animation studios. 2021’s "The Mitchells vs the Machines" and
2022’s "Puss in Boots" take non-photorealistic rendering in a different,
more painterly direction where out-of-focus objects 
become simplified shapes emulating the way that artists may use 
simplified marks in backgrounds "In the Mitchells vs the Machines", shadows
create different marker textures. Puss in Boots’ simplified 2D cutaways mimic
the graphic bursts of Into the Spider-verse. People were like, "Oh, this is looks really
good and it's different". So now, all future projects at studios from
DreamWorks and Imageworks and Pixar— they're looking at the next whatever, five
years or whatnot. It's all like very stylized. And that’s really exciting because non-photorealism allows animated movies
to take advantage of the things that make them special. They can be anything the imagination allows.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Rendering is the process by which:
Options: A. A computer creates an image using internet searches, B. A computer uses AI to make animations move, C. A computer takes geometry, textures, lighting, and camera inputs and applies that information into a final image, D. A computer completes an artist's drawing using algebraic equations
Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Non-photorealism allows animated movies to take advantage of what makes them special. Which is:
Options: A. They can be anything the imagination allows, B. They can have better special effects, C. They can have a larger cast of actors, D. They don't have to rely on the accurate history of the world
Correct Option: A

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On a daily basis, you spend
between a third and half your waking hours daydreaming. That may sound like a huge waste of time, but scientists think it must have 
some purpose, or humans wouldn’t have evolved
to do so much of it. So to figure out what's going on here, let’s take a closer look 
at the mind-wanderer in chief: the bored teenager. Wouldn’t it be cool to discover something,
anything. Like even this plant. Just to be one of those explorers who 
sails around drawing stuff for years on end 
and everyone thinks they’re a genius. But does anyone even do that anymore? Is there anything left to discover? And would I be tough enough to deal 
with the dysentery or scurvy or piranhas or whatever? I barely have the endurance
to make it through track practice... but I will. Any day now, I’ll have the
discipline to show up before sunrise and practice. I’ll win all my races. Winning will become so easy,
I’ll pick up other events just for fun. And once I'm in the Olympics, they’ll have no choice 
but to crown me team captain, which I will graciously accept. And will I be nasty to the teammate
who yelled at me? No. I’ll just calmly say, 
“hope you’re in a better mood.” Okay. Yours and other people's daydreams
might sound or feel something like that. Let's see what was going on. To see what parts of the brain are active when you’re doing a task, or thinking,
or daydreaming, scientists use brain imaging techniques 
that show increased blood flow and energy 
expenditure in those areas. These brain areas are active, working together and communicating
with each other. Taken together, they're called
the executive network. When your mind starts to wander, a different set of brain areas
becomes active. These areas make up the
default mode network. The name default mode makes it sound
like nothing is going on. And in fact, for many years, scientists associated this pattern
of activity with rest. But a closer look reveals that these
are the brain areas involved when we revisit a memory, when we think
about our plans and hopes, and yes, when our minds are wandering
off on a wild daydream. The mind can wander to unproductive
or distressing places and brood over negative past events,
like an argument. It can also wander to neutral,
everyday matters, like planning out the rest
of one's afternoon. But where mind-wandering 
really gets interesting is when it crosses into the realm 
of free-moving associative thought that you aren’t consciously directing. This kind of mind-wandering is associated 
with increases in both ideas and positive emotions, and the evidence suggests that daydreaming
can help people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate
relationships and social situations. Scientists think there may be 
two essential parts to this process: a generative phase of free-flowing ideas
and spontaneous thoughts, courtesy of the default mode network, followed by a process of selecting, 
developing, and pursuing the best ideas from that generative burst, driven by logical thinking 
thanks to the executive network. A host of imaging studies suggest that
these two networks working in sync is a crucial condition 
for creative thinking. Taken together, the evidence clearly
suggests the logical realm of the executive network and the imaginative realm 
of the default mode network are closely related. And as you can see, the executive network
is still playing a role when the default mode network is
doing its thing during daydreaming. In teenagers, the prefrontal cortex and other areas
involved in executive function are still developing, but teens are perfectly capable of 
thinking through their problems and goals, especially when given space to do so
on their own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Between what percentage do humans spend their days daydreaming?
Options: A. Between one quarter and one third, B. Between one third and one half, C. Between one half and three quarters, D. Almost all the time
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What percentage of waking hours do people spend daydreaming, according to scientists? Options: A. 10-20%, B. 20-30%, C. Between a third and half, D. 50-60% Correct Option: C
Question 2: According to the transcript, what is the name of the brain network that is active when the mind starts to wander? Options: A. Executive Network, B. Default Mode Network, C. Both A and B, D. Neither A nor B Correct Option: B
Question 3: If you were to imagine yourself winning all your races and becoming an Olympic team captain, what would be a potential outcome of your daydreaming? Options: A. You would lose motivation to practice, B. You would develop a negative attitude towards your teammates, C. You would become a more confident and disciplined athlete, D. You would give up on your goals Correct Option: C
Question 4: According to the transcript, what are the two essential parts to the process of mind-wandering that helps people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate relationships and social situations? Options: A. A generative phase of free-flowing ideas and a process of selecting, developing, and pursuing the best ideas, B. A process of selecting and developing the best ideas and a generative phase of free-flowing ideas, C. A generative phase of free-flowing ideas and a process of logical thinking, D. A process of logical thinking and a generative phase of free-flowing ideas Correct Option: A
Question 5: What is the relationship between the executive network and the default mode network, according to the transcript? Options: A. They are separate and distinct networks, B. They are closely related and work together in sync, C. The executive network is a subset of the default mode network, D. The default mode network is a subset of the executive network Correct Option: B
Question 6: According to the transcript, what is the potential benefit of daydreaming? Options: A. It can help people develop a negative attitude towards others, B. It can help people become more focused and disciplined, C. It can help people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate relationships and social situations, D. It can help people give up on their goals Correct Option: C
Question 7: What is the name of the brain imaging technique that shows increased blood flow and energy expenditure in the brain areas that are active when the mind is doing a task, thinking, or daydreaming? Options: A. Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging (fMRI), B. Positron Emission Tomography (PET), C. Electroencephalography (EEG), D. None of the above Correct Option: A
Question 8: According to the transcript, what is the role of the prefrontal cortex in teenagers? Options: A. It is fully developed and responsible for executive function, B. It is still developing and not fully responsible for executive function, C. It is not involved in executive function, D. It is responsible for emotional regulation Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the potential outcome of mind-wandering crossing into the realm of free-moving associative thought that is not consciously directed? Options: A. It can lead to a decrease in creative thinking, B. It can lead to a decrease in positive emotions, C. It can lead to an increase in both ideas and positive emotions, D. It can lead to a decrease in motivation Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between logical thinking and creative thinking? Options: A. They are mutually exclusive and cannot coexist, B. They are closely related and can work together in sync, C. Logical thinking is a subset of creative thinking, D. Creative thinking is a subset of logical thinking Correct Option: B
Question 11: According to the transcript, why do scientists think humans have evolved to spend a significant amount of time daydreaming? Options: A. Because it is a waste of time, B. Because it has some purpose, C. Because it is a result of boredom, D. Because it is a result of genetics Correct Option: B
Question 12: What is the name of the brain network that is active when a person is revisiting a memory, thinking about their plans and hopes, and daydreaming? Options: A. Executive Network of attention, B. Executive Network, C. Default Mode Network, D. Network of emotional regulation Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On a daily basis, you spend
between a third and half your waking hours daydreaming. That may sound like a huge waste of time, but scientists think it must have 
some purpose, or humans wouldn’t have evolved
to do so much of it. So to figure out what's going on here, let’s take a closer look 
at the mind-wanderer in chief: the bored teenager. Wouldn’t it be cool to discover something,
anything. Like even this plant. Just to be one of those explorers who 
sails around drawing stuff for years on end 
and everyone thinks they’re a genius. But does anyone even do that anymore? Is there anything left to discover? And would I be tough enough to deal 
with the dysentery or scurvy or piranhas or whatever? I barely have the endurance
to make it through track practice... but I will. Any day now, I’ll have the
discipline to show up before sunrise and practice. I’ll win all my races. Winning will become so easy,
I’ll pick up other events just for fun. And once I'm in the Olympics, they’ll have no choice 
but to crown me team captain, which I will graciously accept. And will I be nasty to the teammate
who yelled at me? No. I’ll just calmly say, 
“hope you’re in a better mood.” Okay. Yours and other people's daydreams
might sound or feel something like that. Let's see what was going on. To see what parts of the brain are active when you’re doing a task, or thinking,
or daydreaming, scientists use brain imaging techniques 
that show increased blood flow and energy 
expenditure in those areas. These brain areas are active, working together and communicating
with each other. Taken together, they're called
the executive network. When your mind starts to wander, a different set of brain areas
becomes active. These areas make up the
default mode network. The name default mode makes it sound
like nothing is going on. And in fact, for many years, scientists associated this pattern
of activity with rest. But a closer look reveals that these
are the brain areas involved when we revisit a memory, when we think
about our plans and hopes, and yes, when our minds are wandering
off on a wild daydream. The mind can wander to unproductive
or distressing places and brood over negative past events,
like an argument. It can also wander to neutral,
everyday matters, like planning out the rest
of one's afternoon. But where mind-wandering 
really gets interesting is when it crosses into the realm 
of free-moving associative thought that you aren’t consciously directing. This kind of mind-wandering is associated 
with increases in both ideas and positive emotions, and the evidence suggests that daydreaming
can help people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate
relationships and social situations. Scientists think there may be 
two essential parts to this process: a generative phase of free-flowing ideas
and spontaneous thoughts, courtesy of the default mode network, followed by a process of selecting, 
developing, and pursuing the best ideas from that generative burst, driven by logical thinking 
thanks to the executive network. A host of imaging studies suggest that
these two networks working in sync is a crucial condition 
for creative thinking. Taken together, the evidence clearly
suggests the logical realm of the executive network and the imaginative realm 
of the default mode network are closely related. And as you can see, the executive network
is still playing a role when the default mode network is
doing its thing during daydreaming. In teenagers, the prefrontal cortex and other areas
involved in executive function are still developing, but teens are perfectly capable of 
thinking through their problems and goals, especially when given space to do so
on their own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What's the name of the network in the brain that's associated with daydreaming?
Options: A. Executive Network, B. Dorsal Attention Network, C. Default Mode Network, D. Salience Network
Correct Option: C

If the default mode network in your brain is active, you are most likely:

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 21, Question 5
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
On a daily basis, you spend
between a third and half your waking hours daydreaming. That may sound like a huge waste of time, but scientists think it must have 
some purpose, or humans wouldn’t have evolved
to do so much of it. So to figure out what's going on here, let’s take a closer look 
at the mind-wanderer in chief: the bored teenager. Wouldn’t it be cool to discover something,
anything. Like even this plant. Just to be one of those explorers who 
sails around drawing stuff for years on end 
and everyone thinks they’re a genius. But does anyone even do that anymore? Is there anything left to discover? And would I be tough enough to deal 
with the dysentery or scurvy or piranhas or whatever? I barely have the endurance
to make it through track practice... but I will. Any day now, I’ll have the
discipline to show up before sunrise and practice. I’ll win all my races. Winning will become so easy,
I’ll pick up other events just for fun. And once I'm in the Olympics, they’ll have no choice 
but to crown me team captain, which I will graciously accept. And will I be nasty to the teammate
who yelled at me? No. I’ll just calmly say, 
“hope you’re in a better mood.” Okay. Yours and other people's daydreams
might sound or feel something like that. Let's see what was going on. To see what parts of the brain are active when you’re doing a task, or thinking,
or daydreaming, scientists use brain imaging techniques 
that show increased blood flow and energy 
expenditure in those areas. These brain areas are active, working together and communicating
with each other. Taken together, they're called
the executive network. When your mind starts to wander, a different set of brain areas
becomes active. These areas make up the
default mode network. The name default mode makes it sound
like nothing is going on. And in fact, for many years, scientists associated this pattern
of activity with rest. But a closer look reveals that these
are the brain areas involved when we revisit a memory, when we think
about our plans and hopes, and yes, when our minds are wandering
off on a wild daydream. The mind can wander to unproductive
or distressing places and brood over negative past events,
like an argument. It can also wander to neutral,
everyday matters, like planning out the rest
of one's afternoon. But where mind-wandering 
really gets interesting is when it crosses into the realm 
of free-moving associative thought that you aren’t consciously directing. This kind of mind-wandering is associated 
with increases in both ideas and positive emotions, and the evidence suggests that daydreaming
can help people envision ways to reach their goals and navigate
relationships and social situations. Scientists think there may be 
two essential parts to this process: a generative phase of free-flowing ideas
and spontaneous thoughts, courtesy of the default mode network, followed by a process of selecting, 
developing, and pursuing the best ideas from that generative burst, driven by logical thinking 
thanks to the executive network. A host of imaging studies suggest that
these two networks working in sync is a crucial condition 
for creative thinking. Taken together, the evidence clearly
suggests the logical realm of the executive network and the imaginative realm 
of the default mode network are closely related. And as you can see, the executive network
is still playing a role when the default mode network is
doing its thing during daydreaming. In teenagers, the prefrontal cortex and other areas
involved in executive function are still developing, but teens are perfectly capable of 
thinking through their problems and goals, especially when given space to do so
on their own.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What does the evidence suggest about the relationship between the more logical side of our brain (the executive network) and the more creative side of our brain (the default mode network)?
Options: A. They are totally separate from one another, B. They cannot operate simultaneously, C. That they can be related to one another and active at the same time, D. That they often come into conflict with one another
Correct Option: C
